overview_of_class: In this course, we will examine central issues in social epistemology with a special focus on disagreement, the norms governing our assessment of the credibility of others, the nature of testimonial injustice, the extent to which silence can confer positive epistemic status, and the knowledge attributed to groups (such as corporations and universities).
name: Seminar in Epistemology
title: WCAS PHIL 468-0-20 Seminar in Epistemology
enrl_requirement: Enrollment Requirements: Registration is reserved for Philosophy PhD Graduate Students

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, we will examine central issues in social epistemology with a special focus on disagreement, the norms governing our assessment of the credibility of others, the nature of testimonial injustice, the extent to which silence can confer positive epistemic status, and the knowledge attributed to groups (such as corporations and universities).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The abilities to think, read, and write critically, to develop and defend arguments, and to appropriately justify one's views will be emphasized.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two 3-5 page papers, each worth 15% of the final grade; one 7-8 page presentation, worth 20% of the final grade; and one 12-15 page final paper, worth 40% of the final grade.

subject: PHIL
